articles.headline: New Unemployment Claims Decline, but Remain ‘Alarmingly High’
articles.snippet: Nearly 1.2 million filed for state benefits last week, the lowest total since March, as economic readings offer only limited encouragement.
articles.abstract: Nearly 1.2 million filed for state benefits last week, the lowest total since March, as economic readings offer only limited encouragement.
articles.lead_paragraph: The government reported on Thursday that nearly 1.2 million workers filed new claims for state unemployment benefits last week. It was the lowest weekly total since March, but signaled the continuing damage that the pandemic is inflicting on the labor market.

articles.headline: Amid Dire Jobless Numbers, Small-Business Relief Program Nears End
articles.snippet: The Paycheck Protection Program provided respite for hard-hit small businesses, but it is ending soon. With no word on further government help, owners worry about their fate.
articles.abstract: The Paycheck Protection Program provided respite for hard-hit small businesses, but it is ending soon. With no word on further government help, owners worry about their fate.
articles.lead_paragraph: In early April, three weeks after Connecticut issued shutdown orders, Ken Bodenstein borrowed $148,000 from the federal government to help cover payroll expenses at the Westport day care center he runs with his wife, Kristen.

articles.headline: They’re Children at Risk of Abuse, and Their Caseworkers Are Stuck Home
articles.snippet: Scores of investigations into allegations of abuse or neglect have been delayed or sharply curtailed during the coronavirus pandemic, records and interviews show.
articles.abstract: Scores of investigations into allegations of abuse or neglect have been delayed or sharply curtailed during the coronavirus pandemic, records and interviews show.
articles.lead_paragraph: TOLLHOUSE, Calif. — In February, the child abuse hotline for Tollhouse, a small community in the Central Valley, received the first of several tips raising urgent concerns about the well-being of twin infant boys.
articles.byline: By Garrett Therolf, Daniel Lempres and Aksaule Alzhan

articles.headline: Investors Cozy Up to Danish Stocks
articles.snippet: Denmark is enjoying one of the best-performing stock markets in the world this year. Recession-proof businesses and a strong safety net equal big gains.
articles.abstract: Denmark is enjoying one of the best-performing stock markets in the world this year. Recession-proof businesses and a strong safety net equal big gains.
articles.lead_paragraph: Denmark is a place of hygge, happiness and — in the face of a global downturn — a high-performing stock market.

articles.headline: Abolish the Police? Those Who Survived the Chaos in Seattle Aren’t So Sure
articles.snippet: What is it like when a city abandons a neighborhood and the police vanish? Business owners describe a harrowing experience of calling for help and being left all alone.
articles.abstract: What is it like when a city abandons a neighborhood and the police vanish? Business owners describe a harrowing experience of calling for help and being left all alone.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEATTLE — Faizel Khan was being told by the news media and his own mayor that the protests in his hometown were peaceful, with “a block party atmosphere.”

articles.headline: In a Wistful Age, Farmers Find a New Angle: Chore TV
articles.snippet: It’s hard for small farmers to earn a living selling their products. Enter the “farmer-influencer,” who can earn more by streaming farm life, in all its comforting monotony, to a growing online audience.
articles.abstract: It’s hard for small farmers to earn a living selling their products. Enter the “farmer-influencer,” who can earn more by streaming farm life, in all its comforting monotony, to a growing online audience.
articles.lead_paragraph: PEACHAM, Vt. — The sweet smell of hay rose off the earth on a recent evening, as Morgan Gold strode across his farmyard in heavy boots. He crossed the paddock, scanning for new eggs, water levels, infected peck wounds, rips in the fence line.

articles.headline: Targeting WeChat, Trump Takes Aim at China’s Bridge to the World
articles.snippet: The all-purpose app, which the administration is restricting along with TikTok, is how many Chinese living abroad stay in touch with one another, and with people back home.
articles.abstract: The all-purpose app, which the administration is restricting along with TikTok, is how many Chinese living abroad stay in touch with one another, and with people back home.
articles.lead_paragraph: TAIPEI, Taiwan — In China, WeChat does more than any app rightfully should. People use it to talk, shop, share photos, pay bills, get their news and send money.
articles.byline: By Paul Mozur and Raymond Zhong
